docs.lead_paragraph: Once Facebook increases its advertising, its shares are expected to climb, but for now they are down.
docs.abstract: Facebook shares fall nearly 4 percent to $20.88, nearly half of what they were worth when the company went public on May 17; its shares are expected to climb once it increases its advertising.

docs.snippet: To Harry Markowitz, the father of modern portfolio theory, the Facebook stock hubbub is a yawn. He’d rather focus on a rigorously diversified mix of stocks and bonds....
docs.lead_paragraph: To Harry Markowitz, the father of modern portfolio theory, the Facebook stock hubbub is a yawn. He’d rather focus on a rigorously diversified mix of stocks and bonds.
docs.abstract: Jeff Sommer Strategies column addresses the puzzling swing in Facebook's first day of trading; cites Harry M Markowitz, Nobel laureate in economics, who believes investors should not worry too much about gyrations in big stocks in the news, but instead should assemble diversified portfolios of stocks and bonds with a mix of risk and return optimized for their own needs and beliefs.

headline.seo: Facebook’s Swings Are Ho-Hum to a Nobel Laureate

docs.lead_paragraph: An independent florist with a reputation for unusual arrangements, Bloom is a fixture in historic downtown Bentonville, Ark., an area whose rapid growth was recently accelerated by the opening of the Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art.
docs.abstract: There was one big problem: the business had to be sold in four months -- before the seller was going to pack up and move to Chicago to take a job.

docs.snippet: On Wednesday, Facebook's law firm Fenwick & West halted the clearance of trades for Facebook shares on the secondary market, according to people with knowledge of the matter, reports Evelyn M. Rusli in DealBook....
docs.lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, Facebook's law firm Fenwick & West halted the clearance of trades for Facebook shares on the secondary market, according to people with knowledge of the matter who spoke on the condition of anonymity because the transactions are private, reports Evelyn M. Rusli in DealBook. While trades may still occur on the secondary markets, the firm will not officially sign-off on any transfers until Monday, the people said. Read more »
